Therefore, zero substitutions here.

Moving on to part b), converting leucine (LEU) to alanine (ALN). LEU is L-461, while ALN is A-461. The difference is just the substitution of L with A. So one substitution needed.

Next, part c) involves changing phenylalanine (Phe) to glycine ( Gly). Phe is F-409, and glycine is G-407. To go from F to G, you replace F with G, so one substitution again.

For part d), transforming tryptophan (TRP) to serine ( Ser). TRP is T-485, and serine is S-485. Since it's the same position but different amino acids, you have to substitute T with S. That’s another substitution.

Finally, part e) requires changing valine (VLC) to glutamic acid (GLN). V is Leu, and Glu is Glu. Wait, Valine (V) is V-431, and Glu is G-431. So actually, it's the opposite; we're going from V to G. So how do you substitute V with G? Well, V is Leu, and G is Glu. Leu becomes Glu via a substitution at position 2. So that would require replacing V with G, making it one substitution.

Wait, let me double-check. Valine is Leu, and when it's changed to Glu, the second hydroxyl group is replaced. So yes, that's one substitution.
</think>
